perturbation.original_text: 4. Section 31125 of the California Corporation Code requires the franchisor to provide you with a disclosure document before asking you to agree to a material modification of an existing franchise.
perturbation.changed_text: 4. The franchisor is not obligated to provide a disclosure document for material modifications of an existing franchise.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts Section 31125 of the California Corporation Code, which mandates the provision of a disclosure document before a franchisee agrees to a material modification. By stating the franchisor has no such obligation, the modified text creates non-compliance.

perturbation.original_text: 8. You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise. California Corporation Code 31512 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516). Business and Professions Code 20010 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043).
perturbation.changed_text: 8. You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise, regardless of any existing laws. This release includes a complete waiver of all rights under the Franchise Investment Law and the Franchise Relations Act.
perturbation.explanation: This alteration explicitly violates California Corporation Code 31512 and Business and Professions Code 20010, which void waivers of rights under the Franchise Investment Law and Franchise Relations Act, respectively. The modified text mandates a waiver that the law specifically prohibits.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Corporation Code 31512, Business and Professions Code 20010

perturbation.original_text: 10. The Master Franchise Agreement contains a liquidated damages clause. Under California Civil Code Section 1671, certain liquidated damages clauses are unenforceable.
perturbation.changed_text: 10. The Master Franchise Agreement contains a liquidated damages clause, which is fully enforceable regardless of California Civil Code Section 1671.
perturbation.explanation: This modification directly contradicts California Civil Code Section 1671, which states that certain liquidated damages clauses are unenforceable. By asserting that the clause is fully enforceable irrespective of this section, the modified text introduces a legal contradiction.
